CENTERED	0001	366	191	1789	244	<b>Triassic Biptera: descriptions, revisions and phylogenetic</b>
CENTERED	0001	971	255	1184	296	<b>relations</b>
CENTERED	0001	671	373	1521	406	Wieslaw KRZEMINSKI and Ewa KRZEMINSKA 
FOLLOWED	0001	570	657	1879	692	phylogenetic <i>relations. Acta zoologica cracovi ensi a, 46(su ppl.â€” </i>Fossil Insects): 153-184. 
FOLLOWED	0001	570	833	1892	868	<i>assicus, </i>n. gen. et sp. (Nadipteridae), <i>Archilimonia vogesiana, </i>n. gen. et sp. (Archilimo-
FOLLOWED	0001	570	873	1890	908	niidae, n. fam.), <i>Vymrhyphus blagoderovi </i>n. sp. (Protorhyphidae) and <i>Gallia alsatica </i>n. 
FOLLOWED	0001	571	1029	1892	1064	<i>levi </i>and <i>Diletnrnala specula </i>SHCHERBAKOV 1995 is transferred to Mecoptera. The sub-
CENTERED	0001	571	1380	1050	1415	est deposits bearing the Diptera. 
CENTERED	0001	571	1478	679	1513	logeny. 
CENTERED	0001	570	1615	1246	1650	E-maik krzeminski@muzeum.pan.luakow.pl 
CENTERED	0001	692	1654	1181	1689	krzeminska@isez.pan.krakow.pl 
CENTERED	0001	904	1764	1251	1793	I. INTRODUCTION 
CENTERED	0001	264	1912	1891	1950	GRAUVOGEL and Jean-Claude GALL and are dated at the turn of Lower to Middle Triassic (Voltzia-
CENTERED	0001	263	1956	1893	1994	Buntsandstein, c. 240 Ma; GALL a GRAUVOGEL 1966). The collection comprises several thousand 
CENTERED	0001	264	1999	1891	2038	of fossil insects of various orders. Among the Diptera there are larvae, pupae, adults and their sepa-
CENTERED	0001	263	2043	1893	2081	rate wings. Till now one species, <i>Grauvogelia arzvilleriana </i>KRzEMINsKI, KRzEMINsKA 4 PAPIER 
CENTERED	0001	264	2086	1892	2124	(1994) of a new family Grauvogeliidae was described. In the present paper remaining four species 
CENTERED	0001	264	2129	1892	2168	of this collection. They represent main four lineages of the Diptera: Diarchineura, Polyneura, Ani-
CENTERED	0001	266	2397	1894	2435	ous and now representatives of 16 families are known (listed in the Appendix). The first species de-
CENTERED	0001	267	2440	1895	2479	scribed, <i>Crosaphis anomala </i>EVANS 1971 from the Upper Triassic of Australia, was classified 
CENTERED	0001	266	2484	1893	2522	erroneously to the Homoptera; later identified as a dipteran species of Crosaphididae (Anisopodo-
CENTERED	0001	266	2527	1895	2565	morpha) by KovAI.Ev (1983a). Upper Triassic Diptera &amp;om North America were recorded by 
CENTERED	0001	266	2570	1894	2608	OLSEN et al. (1978) and later described by KRZEMINSKI (1992). There were three species represent-
CENTERED	0001	266	2613	1894	2651	ing Limoniidae (Tipulomorpha), one species of Procramptonomyiidae (Anisopodomorpha), one 
CENTERED	0001	267	2656	1894	2694	species of Alinkidae (Tabanomorpha, now Xylophagomorpha) and one specimen incerta sedis of the 
CENTERED	0001	266	2699	1895	2738	Eoptychopteridae (Ptychopteromorpha). Other findings of Triassic Diptera from Ferganskaya Valley 
CENTERED	0001	267	2743	1894	2781	(Kyrgyzstan) were recorded by KovALEv (1983b) and described later by SHcHERBAKov et al. (1995) 
CENTERED	0001	265	2786	1894	2824	together with other Triassic Diptera Irom Central Asia. Thirteen species of five families (Vladipteridae, Li-
CENTERED	0001	266	2829	1892	2868	moniidae, Nadipteridae, Hennigmatidae and Protorhyphidae) were distinguished by these authors. 
CENTERED	0001	267	2967	1895	3006	cramptonomyiidae and Paraxymyiidae and LUKASHEVICH k, SHCHERBAKOV (1999) described a 
CENTERED	0001	265	3011	1895	3049	new family Tillyardipteridae basing on one species. From the Upper Triassic of England the oldest 
CENTERED	0001	267	3054	1895	3093	species of the extant family Chironomidae is known (KRZEMINSKI k JARZEMBOWSKI 1999) and a 
CENTERED	0001	266	3193	1894	3231	dated at the Triassic were later estimated at the Lower Jurassic (GENKINA 1966). All insects de-
CENTERED	0001	267	3237	1894	3275	scribed from the Permian by TILL YARD (1929), RIEK (1977) and WILLMANN (1989) belong to the 
CENTERED	0001	266	3280	1895	3318	Mecoptera. A vast majority of information on fossil Diptera described before 1994 is comprised in 
CENTERED	0001	265	3419	1893	3458	their placement in right taxonomic and phylogenetic context. To enable this, a revision of some Tri-
CENTERED	0001	266	3463	1894	3502	assic and Jurassic materials was necessary (see the Systematic Part). Also discussed are the basic 
CENTERED	0001	267	3602	1895	3640	(Institut de Geologic de 1'Universite Louis Pasteur, Strasbourg) for a loan of Diptera described 
CENTERED	0001	265	3645	1894	3683	herein. We thank also D. SHCHERBAKOV and other Colleagues from the Laboratory of Fossil In-
CENTERED	0001	267	3688	1894	3727	sects, Paleontological Institute RAS in Moscow for making the specimens discussed herein avail-
CENTERED	0001	267	3732	1893	3770	able to us, for their warm (as always) welcome and long, inspiring discussions, which, however, 
CENTERED	0002	777	167	1382	197	II. MATERIAL AND METHODS
CENTERED	0002	266	294	1895	332	lowing Diptera: 54 specimens of <i>Grauvogelia arzvilleriana, </i>at least two larvae of Diptera, several 
CENTERED	0002	265	337	1894	375	pupae and also five adults which are the subject of the present study. Three of them have body par-
CENTERED	0002	265	380	1894	419	tially preserved, and two are Itnown only from separate wings. Their condition is generally poor and 
CENTERED	0002	267	424	1895	462	some of features described below are visible only after a very careful examining in polarized light. All 
CENTERED	0002	267	467	1868	505	specimens are covered with a diluted Arabic gum which prevents their wetting with water or alcohol.
CENTERED	0002	266	641	1894	680	two anal veins, a system usually applied in the Tipulomorpha. This system is both the simplest one 
CENTERED	0002	266	685	1894	723	and most probably homologous with that of higher Mecoptera (Fig. 1). Although hypothetic 
CENTERED	0002	266	728	1895	766	groundplans of Diptera venation (MCALPINE 1981: Fig. 2.67, after HENNIG 1973: Fig. 111) present 
CENTERED	0002	267	771	1893	810	a basal cubital vein forked in two veins (CuA1 and CuA2), such pattern does not occur in any Me-
CENTERED	0002	266	815	1894	853	coptera with dipteroidal venation, nor in most primitive Diptera (fossil and Recent representatives
FOLLOWED	0002	1809	2045	1825	2058	<i>ttt </i>
CENTERED	0002	1626	1130	1715	1162	) tta M 
CENTERED	0002	1625	1246	1715	1262	O W O 
CENTERED	0002	1626	1294	1679	1316	<b><i>O </b></i>Q 
CENTERED	0002	1699	1358	1715	1372	a5 
CENTERED	0002	1662	1383	1715	1404	p M 
CENTERED	0002	1625	1423	1658	1438	O ' 
CENTERED	0002	1625	1446	1715	1463	tttt O M 
CENTERED	0002	1626	1462	1642	1479	O 
CENTERED	0002	1662	1511	1715	1524	M O 
CENTERED	0002	1618	1524	1679	1547	'tttt VM 
CENTERED	0002	1626	1548	1678	1564	tt! p 
CENTERED	0002	1626	1642	1642	1656	ttt 
CENTERED	0002	1699	1714	1715	1725	M 
CENTERED	0002	1626	1727	1715	1747	P V g 
CENTERED	0002	1625	1929	1710	1950	M'Op 
CENTERED	0002	1619	2012	1715	2038	Q~ c! 
CENTERED	0002	1662	2032	1715	2071	tttl g 
CENTERED	0002	1613	2109	1715	2156	<i>'~o </i>ES 
CENTERED	0002	1662	2245	1678	2255	<b>M </b>
CENTERED	0002	1618	2256	1715	2276	~ O Mt 
CENTERED	0002	1618	2330	1678	2344	V tt! 
CENTERED	0002	1625	2400	1642	2413	M 
CENTERED	0002	1626	2454	1636	2463	v 
CENTERED	0002	1626	2538	1715	2561	tt! + ttl 
CENTERED	0002	1662	2556	1678	2569	<b>0 </b>
CENTERED	0002	1699	2571	1715	2582	M 
CENTERED	0002	1626	2654	1715	2687	Q W 'P 
CENTERED	0002	1626	2685	1715	2699	ttt V 
CENTERED	0002	1625	2753	1642	2768	O 
CENTERED	0002	1619	2798	1715	2827	+AD 
CENTERED	0002	1626	2824	1678	2849	ttt E 
CENTERED	0002	1699	2851	1715	2865	ttt 
CENTERED	0002	1692	3122	1715	3136	Ch, 
CENTERED	0002	1736	1194	1752	1209	0
CENTERED	0002	1728	1877	1752	1890	QO
CENTERED	0002	1736	2476	1751	2485	V
CENTERED	0002	1735	2509	1751	2520	V
CENTERED	0002	1731	2520	1752	2529	V
CENTERED	0002	1736	2946	1751	2959	O
CENTERED	0002	1736	2961	1751	2976	p
CENTERED	0003	264	32	1891	70	of both groups included). In these groups we find invariably one basal medial vein Mb forked into 
CENTERED	0003	263	75	1892	113	two branches, which in Mecoptera fork dichotomically into numerous medial veins. In the Diptera 
CENTERED	0003	263	118	1891	157	these are reduced to four ones, Ml - M4 in a sequence of reductions which can be traced easily in the 
CENTERED	0003	263	162	1891	200	Permian Mecoptera with dipteroidal venation (Fig. 1). Also invariably, in both groups the cross-
CENTERED	0003	263	205	1892	243	vein m-cu connects the medial vein with the cubital one (Fig. 1). This position and role of cross-vein 
CENTERED	0003	263	248	1892	287	m-cu has been misinterpreted in the groundplan of Diptera by MCALPINE (1981: Fig. 2.67 ) where 
CENTERED	0003	263	292	1875	330	this cross-vein is considered a basal section of CuA1, while a basal section of M4 plays the role of m-cu. 
CENTERED	0003	847	368	1308	397	III. SYSTEMATIC PART 
CENTERED	0003	858	443	1298	472	<b>ORDER: MKCOPTKRA </b>
CENTERED	0003	701	517	1452	556	Family: <b>Vladipteridae </b>SHCHERBAKOV 1995 
CENTERED	0003	263	642	1889	680	Asia) by SHcHERBAKov (in: SHcHERBAKov et al. 1995) and originally comprised two subfamilies: 
CENTERED	0003	265	784	1891	823	SHCHERBAKOV and <i>Dilemmala specula </i>SHCHERBAKOV. My (WK) repeated, meticulous reexami-
CENTERED	0003	263	832	1893	871	nation of these holotypes resulted in stating that <i>Vladiptera kovalevi does </i>not belong to Diptera and 
CENTERED	0003	264	880	1891	918	should be classified to the Mecoptera with dipteroidal venation, similar to that in <i>Robinjohnia til-</i>
CENTERED	0003	264	927	1891	966	<i>lyardi </i>RIEK (Fig. 1D) or <i>Permotipula patricia </i>TILLYARD (Fig. 1E), or <i>Permila borealis </i>(MARTY-
CENTERED	0003	262	975	1892	1013	NOvA). V. <i>kovalevi </i>(Fig. 1F) has two cubital and two anal veins (CuA, CuP, Al and A2, according 
CENTERED	0003	263	1022	1892	1061	to SHCHERBAKOV et al. 1995), as, ex., in <i>Aobinjohnia </i>and <i>Permila. </i>Till now this pattern is known 
CENTERED	0003	263	1165	1893	1203	whether it belongs to the four- or two-winged specimen; the venation, according to our present 
CENTERED	0003	263	1212	1891	1250	knowledge, speaks for a four-winged insect, probably of the Mecoptera. However, if an undoubt-
CENTERED	0003	264	1259	1893	1298	edly two-winged specimen with that venation is found in future, the four veins in cubito-anal field 
CENTERED	0003	263	1307	1893	1345	would deserve a distinguished position among the Diptera, at least of a separate suborder, a sister 
CENTERED	0003	264	1448	1893	1486	classification to the Diptera is also insufficiently based. Summarizing, the Vladipteridae (without 
CENTERED	0003	263	1495	1891	1534	Psychotipinae) belong in our opinion to the Triassic Mecoptera with dipteroidal venation, a group 
CENTERED	0003	264	1733	1890	1771	and <i>P. depicta </i>SHCHERBAKOV 1995, were originally described as a subfamily of Vladipteridae. 
CENTERED	0003	263	1780	1893	1819	They have three veins in cubito-anal field and undoubtedly belong the Diptera. The long A2 vein 
CENTERED	0003	262	1828	1891	1866	places them safely within the Polyneura, infraorder Tipulomorpha, as a separate family Psychotipi-
CENTERED	0003	264	1875	1891	1913	dae, comb. nov. (see Appendix and Fig. 7). Differences in wing venation between its two species in-
CENTERED	0003	898	1999	1258	2028	<b>ORDER: DIPTKRA </b>
CENTERED	0003	264	2118	1893	2157	evidence earlier radiation of this group into different lineages, as will be presented later. Therefore it 
CENTERED	0003	264	2164	1891	2202	seems plausible that Diptera had branched off the main stem of the Mecoptera about the turn of Per-
CENTERED	0003	263	2209	1892	2247	mian to the Triassic. It is very probable that Diptera originated from Permochoristidae (Fig. 1), very 
CENTERED	0003	264	2254	1891	2293	common during the Permian, or from other mecopteran lineage close to this family. Permian Me-
CENTERED	0003	264	2300	1897	2338	coptera exhibited a strong tendency to a). reduction of venation in fore wings, and b). reduction of 
CENTERED	0003	262	2595	1891	2633	Permochoristidae, Robinjohniidae, Permotipulidae and Laurentipteridae; Fig. 1), and also are pres-
CENTERED	0003	263	2640	1891	2679	ent in Recent Mecoptera. For instance, Nannochoristidae show reduced wing venation, while Bor-
CENTERED	0003	263	2686	1893	2724	eidae and Apteropanorpidae have wings strongly reduced. WOOD k BORKENT (1989) had even 
CENTERED	0003	264	2731	1891	2769	supposed that Nannochoristidae could be a sister group to the Diptera + Siphonaptera. However, 
CENTERED	0003	262	2776	1891	2815	this idea lacks the evidence, because according to NOVOKSHONOV (1997) the oldest Nannochoristi-
CENTERED	0003	263	2822	1893	2860	dae are not known before the Lower Jurassic, and the Siphonaptera stay closer to the Mecoptera 
CENTERED	0003	263	2964	1891	3002	reduction of wing venation in Mecoptera can be observed. The same parallel tendency in Diptera is 
CENTERED	0003	263	3117	1891	3156	ous apomorphies. However, wings of the oldest Diptera do not differ so much from some mecop-
CENTERED	0003	263	3163	1892	3202	teran wings; hence the difficulties in classifying single fossil wings (see the section on 
CENTERED	0003	263	3462	1897	3500	Transformation of the mecopteran hind wing into a dipteran haltere is the primordial apomorphy of 
CENTERED	0003	263	3507	1892	3545	the Diptera. Sometimes only a finding of a body with wings allows to discern oldest Triassic and 
CENTERED	0003	263	3552	1892	3591	Diptera from the Mecoptera, because wing venation of separate wings in both orders happens to be 
CENTERED	0003	262	3598	1892	3636	too similar to ensure safe classification to the order. Examples of such errors are known (TILLYARD 
CENTERED	0003	267	3643	1892	3681	1929, 1937; RIEK 1977; JELL 4 DUNcAN 1986; WILLMANN 1989); separate wings were originally 
CENTERED	0003	263	3688	1891	3727	classified to the Diptera by these authors, and only later findings of more complete specimens al-
CENTERED	0003	263	3734	1891	3772	lowed to verify their position and to transfer them to the Mecoptera. Most probably, this will be also 
CENTERED	0004	263	60	1892	98	tion can be very similar to the dipteran one. Only two differences seem to exist: Diptera have only 
CENTERED	0004	263	105	1893	144	one cubital vein, probably CuA (in result of complete reduction of the second, probably CuP), and 
CENTERED	0004	262	248	1891	287	present at base of anal field in many Recent Diptera: Tanyderidae, Ptychopteridae, Anisopodidae, 
CENTERED	0004	263	294	1890	332	Cramptonomyiidae, and almost all Lower Brachycera. Only a find of <i>Grauvogelia arzvilleriana, </i>
CENTERED	0004	263	338	1891	377	the hitherto oldest Diptera (Lower/Middle Triassic of France; KRzEMINSKI et al. 1994), allowed to 
CENTERED	0004	262	384	1893	423	recognize its previous, ancestral shape and propose its possible homology with second and third 
CENTERED	0004	263	430	1891	468	anal vein of the Mecoptera. A grauvogeliid anal loop is the fully developed vein with scarce bristles 
CENTERED	0004	264	475	1892	513	(Fig ICr). A similar anal loop is also known in some Lepidoptera and Trichoptera (KRzEMINsKI et 
CENTERED	0004	264	520	1891	558	al. 1994; KRzEMINSKI k EvENHUIS 2000). The anal loop, well developed in <i>G. arzvi lleriana, </i>under-
CENTERED	0004	263	566	1891	604	went a stepwise reduction in some lineages, and vanished completely in others (ex. higher Brachyc-
CENTERED	0004	263	611	1892	649	era); while in other (Polyneura), quite contrarily, it have been expanded into a long anal vein. All 
CENTERED	0004	262	754	1891	793	tionally, it partially fulfills the role of a hind wing of Mecoptera. Hence isolated mecopteran wings 
CENTERED	0004	263	800	1893	838	can be usually recognized by the lack of anal lobe; the wing base is narrowed in petiole-like way, or 
CENTERED	0004	263	845	1892	883	even excised to make place for a smaller hind wing (as in <i>Laurentiptera galliea </i>LAURENTIAUX et 
CENTERED	0004	263	890	1892	928	CrRAUVQGEL (in LAURENTIAUx 1953); illustrated in KRzEMINsKI k KRzEMINsKA 1996 and in 
CENTERED	0004	262	936	1892	974	KRZEMINSKI k, EvENHUIS 2000: Fig 10). Also the connection of wing with the body is generafly 
CENTERED	0004	263	981	1893	1019	more narrow in Diptera, allowing better maneuverability of the wing. In some advanced Recent
CENTERED	0004	265	1190	1895	1228	Diptera the anal lobe is absent (Psychodidae, Vermileonidae), but most Diptera have it. Exception
CENTERED	0004	266	1236	1891	1274	are some separate wings of unrecognized origin, as Vladipteridae or Crnomuscidae (discussed later).

CENTERED	0004	265	3463	1895	3494	Fig. 2. General phylogenetic system of the Diptera. Triassic Diptera evidence rapid radiation of the order and show distinct 
CENTERED	0004	301	3500	1895	3531	division into five main evolutionary lineages: Diarchineura, Neoneura, Polyneura, Anisoneura and Brachycera (after 
CENTERED	0004	300	3537	1858	3568	KRZEMINSKI k EVENHUIS 2000). Relations within particular lineages are presented separately (Figs 3, 6, 7, 10, 12, 13).
CENTERED	0004	668	3737	1492	3772	<b>SUBORDER: MARCHINKURA </b>KRZEMINSKI, 1992
CENTERED	0005	265	78	1895	116	new fossil Diptera described since that time require updating of diagnosis as follows). Five radial 
CENTERED	0005	265	125	1895	164	veins terminate in wing margin; cross-vein r-r absent; four medial veins present; second anal vein 
CENTERED	0005	266	272	1894	311	Tanyderidae and Psychodidae); sc-r at base of Sc (Grauvogeliidae, Nadipteridae), in mid of Sc 
CENTERED	0005	267	320	1894	358	(Hennigmatidae) or at end (Tanyderidae, Psychodidae); five radial and four medial veins terminat-
CENTERED	0005	266	367	1894	405	ing in wing margin (only in some fossil and Recent Psychodidae the radial and medial veins are par-
CENTERED	0005	265	414	1895	453	tially reduced, but this reduction can be always recognized as obvious apomorphy). Discal cell 
CENTERED	0005	265	462	1893	500	variable, usually rather large, and/or conspicuously elongated (Hennigmatidae, Nadipteridae, 
CENTERED	0005	266	509	1895	548	Tanyderidae, some fossil Psychodidae); only in Psychodidae open by atrophy of cross-vein m-m 
CENTERED	0005	265	557	1894	596	between M2 and M3; in majority of Diarchineura d cell is petiolate, i.e., a free section of Ml+2 is 
CENTERED	0005	265	605	1894	643	present beyond d cell (petiole absent only in Tanyderidae and Psychodidae). Cross-vein m-cu usu-
CENTERED	0005	266	652	1895	691	ally in distal portion of M3+4 (i.e., at base of d cell), sometimes in fork of this vein or beyond it (then 
CENTERED	0005	266	700	1893	738	directly attached to M4); only in Grauvogeliomorpha in mid of M3+4. Between Cu and Al pseu-
CENTERED	0005	266	747	1893	785	dovein usually present (no trace of it only in Grauvogeliidae). Second anal vein forming character-
CENTERED	0005	266	794	1893	833	istic loop, probably homologous to and arisen from two anal veins (A2 and A3) of Mecoptera, 
CENTERED	0005	266	1041	1894	1079	Kuperwoodidae (Upper Triassic), Hennigmatidae (Lower Jurassic to Lower Cretaceous), Nadipte-
CENTERED	0005	265	1088	1895	1127	ridae (Lower/Middle Triassic to Lower Jurassic), and by two Recent families: Tanyderidae (known 
CENTERED	0005	267	1136	1895	1174	since Lower Jurassic) and Psychodidae (known since Middle Jurassic). These families represent 
CENTERED	0005	267	1183	1895	1221	five infraorders: Grauvogeliomorpha, Hennigmatomorpha, Nadipteromorpha, Tanyderomorpha 
CENTERED	0005	266	1230	1895	1269	and Psychodomorpha. Fig. 3 presents their relationships within the Diarchineura, illustrated by

CENTERED	0009	262	320	1891	358	BROEK &amp; COURTNEY 1995; SHCHERBAKOV et al. 1995; MICHELSEN 1996). In our opinion (un-
CENTERED	0009	263	368	1892	406	changed since 1992) this is the most plesiomorphic family still living, a real "living fossil". Some 
CENTERED	0009	263	415	1892	453	fossil Tanyderidae show close relationship with the Psychodidae (KRXEMINSKI 1992; ANSORGE 
CENTERED	0009	814	542	1340	580	<b>Infraorder: Psychodomorpha</b>

CENTERED	0009	262	942	1891	980	rors performed in study on the Diptera evolution. All fossil evidences prove without any doubt close 
CENTERED	0009	262	990	1890	1028	relationship between Psychodidae and Tanyderidae, especially in wing venation (ANSORGE 1994; 
CENTERED	0009	262	1038	1893	1076	KRZEMINSKI &amp;. EvENHUIS 2000). Some Jurassic and Cretaceous Psychodidae had discal cell closed 
CENTERED	0009	263	1086	1891	1124	and venation pattern almost identical with the Tanyderidae, while the Lower Jurassic tanyderids 
CENTERED	0009	263	1133	1890	1172	were small, as are the Recent Psychodidae (KRZEMINSKI 1992; ANSORGE 1994; AZAR et al. 1999; 
CENTERED	0009	263	1281	1897	1320	dustbin for all families of unknown origin. This is evident when comparing phylogenetic trees of 
CENTERED	0009	262	1329	1879	1365	ROHDENDORF 1964; HENNIG 1973; OOS TERBROEK &amp; COURTNEY 1995; SHCHERBAKOV et al. 1995. 
CENTERED	0009	709	1510	1445	1539	<b>SUBORDER: NEOXEURA </b>KRZEMINSKI 1992

CENTERED	0011	265	125	1893	163	ANSORGE 1999) represents the family Chironomidae, a family of much more apomorphic characters 
CENTERED	0011	266	172	1893	211	in the venation than the remaining Culicomorpha, as: Rhaetomyiidae, Chaoboridae or Dixidae, 
CENTERED	0011	265	220	1893	258	which are known from numerous fossils from the Lower and Middle Jurassic (KALUGINA &amp; KOvA-
CENTERED	0011	265	267	1893	306	LEv 1985). Almost certainly these families are much older and their findings among Triassic mate-
CENTERED	0011	269	413	1894	452	1989; BGRKENT 1993; SzADzIEwsKI 1988, 1990, 1995, 1996). Fossil Culicomorpha are dealt with by 
CENTERED	0011	265	461	1894	499	LUKASHEVICH (1996a, b). Phylogeny of the Recent Culicomorpha is extensively discussed by 
CENTERED	0011	560	588	1598	626	<b>Infraorder: Blephariccromorpha </b>WOOD &amp; BORKENT, 1989 
CENTERED	0011	265	717	1893	756	which probably are not closely related. The oldest Blephariceridae are known from the Late Creta-
CENTERED	0011	266	765	1893	803	ceous (KovALEv 1987; LUKAsHEvIcH &amp; SHcHERBAKov 1997). SHcHERBAKov et al. (1995) clas-
CENTERED	0011	266	812	1894	851	sify here also an Upper Jurassic family Ansorgiidae KRZEMINSKI &amp; LUKASHEVICH (1993) from 
CENTERED	0011	603	941	1556	979	<b>Infraorder: Nymphomyiomorpha </b>ROHDENDORF, 1964 
CENTERED	0011	266	1071	1895	1109	(1964), morphology of larvae and adults distinguishes this family among all remaining Diptera and 
CENTERED	0011	266	1118	1895	1157	deserves this separated taxonomic position. Nymphomyiidae stay closer to the Culicomorpha than 
CENTERED	0011	733	1494	1420	1529	<b>SUBORDER: POLYNKURA </b>BRAUER, 1863 
CENTERED	0011	262	1620	1891	1658	vein r-r present, only in Psychotipidae terminating in wing margin as R2, and in some Limoniidae 
CENTERED	0011	262	1766	1892	1804	bly originated from R2, which became vertical and shortened and thus had lost contact with wing 
CENTERED	0011	262	1813	1892	1852	margin to terminate in Rl. This mode of r-r origin was a hypothesis and now is documented within 
CENTERED	0011	263	1861	1893	1899	the Psychotipidae: in some species R2 is not fully contacting Rl, and in some it even terminates in 
CENTERED	0011	264	2007	1893	2045	and Psychotipidae (Fig. 8). Especially the Limoniidae from the Triassic to Recent times present a 
CENTERED	0011	262	2054	1897	2093	model of elongation of A2. This tendency is observed also among the Recent representatives of 
CENTERED	0011	262	2102	1893	2140	young and apomorphic genera of the Limoniidae (e.g., <i>Molophilus, Synzplecta, Erioconopa), </i>and 
CENTERED	0011	662	2314	1489	2352	<b>Infraorder: Tipulomorpha </b>ROHDENDORF, 1961 
CENTERED	0011	264	2441	1891	2479	sented by fossil and Recent species), Psychotipidae (Middle/Upper Triassic) and the oldest â€” Ar-
CENTERED	0011	264	2588	1891	2626	cinae, but expressed some doubts to this classification. We are not sure whether Gnomuscinae are 
CENTERED	0011	263	2636	1892	2674	Diptera at all; but even if so, then they should belong rather Trichoceromorpha, not Tipulomorpha (

CENTERED	0014	798	832	1344	870	Family: <b>Gnomuscidae, </b>comb. n. 
CENTERED	0014	267	952	1892	991	199S) described a subfamily Gnomuscinae within the Limoniidae. It remains doubtful whether both 
CENTERED	0014	264	998	1891	1036	species of the Gnomuscinae, <i>Gnomusca molecula </i>SHcHERBAKov 1995 and G. <i>renyxa </i>SHcHER-
CENTERED	0014	262	1043	1892	1081	BAKOV 1995, belong the Diptera. Again, this is the case of separate wings completely devoid of anal 
CENTERED	0014	263	1248	1892	1286	lobe. Such wings, in our opinion, rather belonged four-winged insects. If the Gnomuscidae are to be 
CENTERED	0014	263	1293	1891	1331	included in the Diptera, their place is rather within the Trichoceromorpha, according to the diagnos-
CENTERED	0014	262	1338	1891	1377	tic character of short anal vein. In that case the group should be given the status of a family Gnomus-
CENTERED	0014	362	1469	1789	1505	<b>NKODIPTKRA </b>MICHELSEN, 1996 j= <b>SUBORDKRS: ANISONKURA AND BRACHYCERA] </b>
CENTERED	0014	262	1598	1891	1636	mented by KRZEMINSKI, KRZEMINSKA &amp; PAPIER (1994) and discussed by KRZEMINSKI &amp; EVEN-
CENTERED	0014	262	1643	1893	1682	HUIs (2000). We assume that from the oldest Diptera â€” the Diarchineura, defined by four 
CENTERED	0014	263	1689	1891	1727	apomorphies, gave origin to younger lineages. Among the first ones were the Anisoneura and Bra-
CENTERED	0014	263	1734	1890	1772	chycera (KRzEMINSKI 1998; KRzEMINSKI &amp; EvENHUIs 2000). According to MICHEI.sEN (1996), 
CENTERED	0014	262	1779	1891	1818	both suborders constitute an informal group called Neodiptera. Recent representatives ofboth sub-
CENTERED	0014	263	1825	1891	1863	orders share some morphologic characters of sclerites; their phylogenetic proximity is also con-
CENTERED	0014	264	1989	1893	2027	sence of R2 (or: r-r) (Fig. 10). Other characters of the lower Anisoneura (as Protorhyphidae) and 
CENTERED	0014	262	2034	1891	2072	Lower Brachycera (as Rhagionidae) are very similar to or identical with the Diarchineura repre-
CENTERED	0014	264	2079	1891	2118	sented by Grauvogeliidae. These plesiomorphic characters are: sc-r close to origin of Sc; r-m proxi-
CENTERED	0014	262	2125	1891	2163	mally of first fork of Rs (into R2+3 and R4+5); d cell rather small and sometimes with petiole 
CENTERED	0014	263	2170	1891	2208	retained ( = free section of M 1+2 beyond d cell); four medial veins; m-cu close to fork of M3+4 into 
CENTERED	0014	262	2215	1891	2254	M3 and M4 (Fig. 3). Fossil materials are scarce, but suggest a one step transition from the Diarchi-
CENTERED	0014	262	2261	1891	2299	neura to Neodiptera. The first, Lower Triassic Neodiptera are: Protorhyphidae (of the Anisoneura) 
CENTERED	0014	263	2306	1892	2344	and Rhagionidae (of Brachycera). Both these lineages had early separated from each other. Judging 
CENTERED	0014	263	2351	1892	2390	from the fossil record, in the Triassic and Lower Jurassic they were poorly represented, (especially 
CENTERED	0014	263	2397	1891	2435	the Brachycera), but since the Middle Jurassic rapid radiation of both lineages is documented, re-
CENTERED	0014	570	2527	1584	2562	<b>SUBORDER: ANISONEURA, </b>KRZEMINSKI &amp; EVENHUIS, 2000 
CENTERED	0014	264	2656	1893	2694	sopodomorpha. The suborder comprises three infraorders: Anisopodomorpha, Axymyiomorpha 
CENTERED	0014	263	2820	1891	2858	Protorhyphidae, which became extinct in the Jurassic. One and the oldest species of this family, de-
CENTERED	0014	264	2865	1891	2903	scribed below, had four long radial and four medial veins, and closed d cell. The direct descendants 
CENTERED	0014	263	2910	1890	2949	of Protorhyphidae are the Anisopodidae, which have lost R4 and have only three radial veins, Rl, 
CENTERED	0014	522	3041	1632	3079	<b>Infraorder: Anisopodomorpha </b>KRZEMINSKI &amp;, EVENHUIS, 2000 
CENTERED	0014	262	3170	1889	3209	phididae, Procramptonomyiidae and Paraxymyiidae. The oldest species is <i>Vymrhyphus blagod-</i>
CENTERED	0014	263	3216	1891	3255	<i>erovi, </i>n. sp. (Protorhyphidae; Lower/Middle Triassic of France) described below. To the same

CENTERED	0018	263	73	1892	111	era (infraorders: Stratiomyomorpha, Xylophagomorpha, Tabanomorpha and Asilomorpha). In 
CENTERED	0018	264	118	1890	157	spite of this, Brachycera are still considered a monophyletic group (YEATES k WIEGMANN 1999). 
CENTERED	0018	263	164	1891	202	This possibly concerns only the so called higher Brachycera, i. e., infraorder Muscomorpha. Gener-
CENTERED	0018	262	306	1891	345	until quite recently. Fossil evidences show that they arose very early, and the oldest are found to-
CENTERED	0018	263	352	1897	390	gether with other oldest representatives of main dipteran lineages in the Lower/Middle Triassic of 
CENTERED	0018	262	637	1893	675	probably Alinkidae, these characters may be not fully expressed, but became so in all more modern 
CENTERED	0018	262	779	1892	817	phagomorpha) were found till now. Since the Middle Jurassic the Brachycera became frequent, and 
CENTERED	0018	264	824	1891	863	started to dominate in the Cretaceous. The Mesozoic Brachycera are reviewed by NAGATOMI k 
CENTERED	0018	263	870	1890	908	YOUNG (1998). Numerous new fossil Brachycera were described recently (KovALEv 1981, 1982; 
CENTERED	0018	262	915	1890	953	MosTovsKI 1996, 1997, 1999; Mos TovsKI k JARzEMBowsKI 2000 and MosTovsKI et al. 2000). 
CENTERED	0018	263	960	1892	999	These findings have improved our comprehension of the evolution of this group and will probably 
CENTERED	0018	830	1119	1324	1157	Infraorder: Tabanomorpha 
CENTERED	0018	264	1241	1890	1280	sidered <i>Palaeobrachyceron liassinum </i>HANDLIRSCH (1920) from the Lower Jurassic of Germany. 
CENTERED	0018	263	1287	1891	1326	With the present description the origin of the Brachycera is pushed back to the Lower/Middle Trias-

CENTERED	0020	262	265	1891	304	Antennae not visible, probably hidden under sediment (further exposing it is risky since the speci-

CENTERED	0020	262	823	1892	861	mere half the length of tibia; 2nd tarsomere c. half the length of 1st (proximal segment border a little 
CENTERED	0020	262	868	1891	907	uncertain); 3rd and 4th tarsomeres are equal and a trifle shorter than 2th one; distal part of 5th tarso-
CENTERED	0020	1060	1071	1252	1109	<b>c </b>s <b>c c </b>a 
CENTERED	0020	262	1637	1893	1668	Fig. 14. <i>Gallia olsaiica </i>n. sp. â€” the oldest Brachycera (Rhaginnidae; Lower/Middle Triassic, France). A. Ieg; B. wing (bar 
CENTERED	0020	264	1896	1893	1934	ence of "short antennae" cannot be proved without a risk of destroying the specimen, the character 
CENTERED	0020	264	1941	1892	1980	of Al and Cu fused at their tips places this specimen close to this lineage. Another very primitive 
CENTERED	0020	264	1987	1892	2025	features are: very short R4+5 and d cell with petiole. Generally, all characters of this specimen show 
CENTERED	0020	264	2032	1891	2070	similarity to primitive Rhagionidae, especially those of the Lower Cretaceous of England (Mos-
CENTERED	0020	803	2159	1352	2197	<b>Infraorder: Xylophagomorpha </b>
CENTERED	0020	263	2285	1891	2323	USA, originally classified to the Tabanomorpha (KRZEMINSKI 1992). The infraorder comprises Re-
CENTERED	0020	264	2330	1891	2368	cent Xylophagidae and extinct Archisargidae and Alinkidae. Judging from their fossil representa-
CENTERED	0020	263	2375	1893	2413	tives, in our opinion also the Acroceridae and Nemestrinidae stay closer Xylophagomorpha and 
CENTERED	0020	794	2502	1361	2540	<b>Infraorder: Stratlomylomorpha </b>
CENTERED	0020	264	2627	1891	2666	(1962) from Karatau (central Asia) and by ANSORGE k KRZEMINSKI (1994) from England. The infra-
CENTERED	0020	264	2673	1891	2711	order comprises also fossil family Eremochaetidae (MOSTOVSKI 1996) and Recent families: Stra-
CENTERED	0020	854	2800	1301	2838	<b>Infraorder: Asilomorpha </b>
CENTERED	0020	264	2927	1892	2965	dae, Therevidae, Bombylidae and Mythicomyiidae). To this infraorder usually also the Empidoidea 
CENTERED	0020	264	2972	1891	3011	are included (families: Empididae and Dolichopodidae). However, we share the opinion of those 
CENTERED	0020	264	3017	1892	3056	authors (HENNIG 1976, CHVA'LA 1983; YEATES X WIEGMANN 1999) who consider Empidoidea a 
CENTERED	0020	840	3242	1314	3280	<b>Infraorder: Museomorpha </b>
CENTERED	0020	264	3368	1892	3406	(Lower Brachycera) and deserve a a rank of a separate suborder. Empidoidea existed already in the 
CENTERED	0020	263	3413	1893	3452	Lower Jurassic (Mos TovsKI 1999), while the majority of the Muscomorpha, the Cyclorrhapha, had 
CENTERED	0020	264	3459	1892	3497	originated not before the Cretaceous (GRIMALDI 1987, 1990; GRIMALDI 8c CUNNING 1999; MOS-
CENTERED	0020	933	3714	1221	3743	CONCLUSIONS
CENTERED	0021	264	83	1892	121	of evolution of the Diptera. The oldest specimens come from the Lower/Middle Triassic of France 
CENTERED	0021	264	128	1893	167	(ca. 240 Ma), but their morphological diversity indicates that the branching off the Mecoptera had 
CENTERED	0021	263	174	1892	212	happened much earlier, probably with the end of the Permian or beginning of the Triassic. These 
CENTERED	0021	264	219	1891	257	first Diptera (only five species known!) already offer a surprisingly wide spectrum of their diver-
CENTERED	0021	264	264	1891	303	sity. Save the Neoneura, all other main lineages (Diarchineura, Polyneura, Anisoneura and Bra-
CENTERED	0021	264	310	1892	348	chycera) are represented among these materials and give evidence of rapid, even explosive 
CENTERED	0021	265	611	1895	649	tanidae, Nadipteridae, Tillyardidae, Psychotipidae, Archilimoniidae n. fam., Protorhyphidae and 
CENTERED	0021	265	658	1895	697	Alinkidae had numerous plesiomorphic characters in their wing venation. On the other hand, from 
CENTERED	0021	265	707	1882	745	the Triassic come some families represented till now: Limoniidae, Rhagionidae and Chironomidae. 
CENTERED	0021	265	806	1892	845	with their primitive venation including a full and functioning anal loop composed of two anal veins. 
CENTERED	0021	267	954	1895	993	and Jurassic flourished also other Diptera of this most primitive suborder, now represented only by 
CENTERED	0021	266	1003	1894	1041	Tanyderidae and Psychodidae, while in the Triassic still lived the Kuperwoodidae, Nadipteridae 
CENTERED	0021	266	1150	1895	1189	Its venation is almost identical with that of primitive Rhagionidae. The idea that Brachycera "must 
CENTERED	0021	265	1199	1894	1237	be" much younger than the Nematocera was so persistent that a find of an Upper Triassic Brachyc-
CENTERED	0021	266	1246	1895	1284	era in 1992 (KRZEMINSKI 1992) was not acceptable to some dipterists at that time. Now the even 
CENTERED	0021	267	1394	1894	1432	assic, it was just this group that had changed most rapidly during the Triassic. While the most primi-
CENTERED	0021	266	1441	1895	1480	tive families: Rhaetaniidae, Tillyardidae and Eoptychopteridae are characterized by large body 
CENTERED	0021	267	1490	1894	1528	size, the tendency to miniaturization and reduction of wing veins appeared early in suborders Culi-
CENTERED	0021	265	1639	1894	1677	wing venation patterns illustrate the mode of transition of a longitudinal radial vein R2 into a cross-
CENTERED	0021	265	1687	1894	1725	vein r-r (Fig. 7). This process had probably been forced by elongating A2 (Fig. 8). Within this sub-
CENTERED	0021	266	1734	1895	1773	order a tendency to gigantism is visible, expressed in the Tipulidae, Cylindrotomidae and partially 
CENTERED	0021	266	1783	1895	1821	also the Limoniidae. Also one giant representative of Trichoceridae of wing size ca. 2 cm is known 
CENTERED	0021	266	1931	1894	1969	group had evolved explosively during the Triassic, which is evidenced by Protorhyphidae Pro-
CENTERED	0021	265	2079	1894	2118	Vladipteridae - had died out. This group of Mecoptera probably did not survive a strong concur-
CENTERED	0021	950	2241	1209	2270	REFERENCES
